comments.body: Thanks for updating! I think we'll need to do this as a two-step process. 1) Update to emptydir. 2) Once we verify it's stable and not flaky, then promote to conformance.
I have raised a separate Issue https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/87810 and will hold this one for the moment
@msau42 Haven't seen any errors in sig testgrid since the HostPath change, so I would guess we're good to go with this one now
I don't see anywhere obvious in the PR tests that has actually performed the conformance prior to merge. Is there any easy way of checking that this PR did some Conformance e2e?
I found that this one `pull-kubernetes-conformance-kind-ipv6-parallel` has performed all 6 conformance tests, so that seems to confirm they are okay
simplify to `f.PodClient()`? (applies to all instances)
You mean just this line? `podClient = f.PodClientNS(f.Namespace.Name)` to this `podClient = f.PodClient()`
yes, PodClient() defaults to f.Namespace.Name
Okay. Thanks. I switched it and retested/ pushed up. I did a squeeze of the commits as well to keep it clean

comments.body: this doesn't really check that the path got resolved correctly and the right file got surfaced in the pod, does it?

Thinking about this some more, I think the subpath mount won't actually change if the env variable changes.  This is because subpath mount cleanup is asymmetrical with setup and they don't get cleaned up until pod termination.  So on a container restart, `makeMounts` will be called again, however, when we get to [prepareSubpathTarget](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/-/blob/pkg/util/mount/nsenter_mount.go#L389:41), we find that the target (whose name doesn't depend on the subpath value), has already been mounted.

So the end behavior is that the subpath value cannot change on container restart.  Only new pods will get the new value.

> So the end behavior is that the subpath value cannot change on container restart. Only new pods will get the new value.

once it succeeds, right? if an unresolvable value prevented successful setup, new values could be picked up on retry, correct?
Correct. Once the subpath has been successfully setup, then it should not change for the lifetime of the pod.  Except... if the node reboots :-/

comments.body: Can we speed up this test by checking for some failed container status?

If I dump the status of the pod immediately after creation, then I get this
```
Status:{Phase:Pending Conditions:[] Message: Reason: NominatedNodeName: HostIP: PodIP: StartTime:<nil> InitContainerStatuses:[] ContainerStatuses:[] QOSClass:BestEffort}}
```
So, I am not sure how to actually wait for the pod to be in its ContainerConfigError state?
I think you can try reusing this: https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/-/blob/test/e2e/storage/testsuites/subpath.go#L647
That test in the subpath seems to still wait - so I didn't use this

comments.body: Can you add one more check that execs into the container, writes a file into the subpath mount, and then verify that file shows up at the expected path wrt to the non-subpath volume mount?  We want to verify that the subpath mount is actually the correct directory.
This check will require you run your container as long running instead of running to completion.

comments.body: I don't think this will actually restart the container.  I don't know of a simple way to trigger a container restart from a test.  For other subpath tests, we used liveness probes to trigger a container restart: https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/-/blob/test/e2e/storage/testsuites/subpath.go#L685

That looks like a very intricate rewrite of the suite but this is what I observe
```
centos7:[root@localhost kubernetes]$ kubectl get pods -n var-expansion-3206 --watch
NAME                                                 READY     STATUS                       RESTARTS   AGE
var-expansion-170a303a-18c2-11e9-8f7a-525400225b53   0/1       CreateContainerConfigError   0          27s
var-expansion-170a303a-18c2-11e9-8f7a-525400225b53   0/1       CreateContainerConfigError   0         2m
var-expansion-170a303a-18c2-11e9-8f7a-525400225b53   1/1       Running   0         2m
var-expansion-170a303a-18c2-11e9-8f7a-525400225b53   1/1       Running   0         2m
var-expansion-170a303a-18c2-11e9-8f7a-525400225b53   1/1       Terminating   0         2m
^Ccentos7:[root@localhost kubernetes]$ kubectl get pods -n var-expansion-3206 -o yaml var-expansion-170a303a-18c2-11e9-8f7a-5254002b53
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  annotations:
    mysubpath: mynewpath
```
The final pod state before the namespace gets deleted, has the new path in it and doesn't the fact that the pod becomes ready after it was in an initial failing state indicate that it got restarted?

So there's two scenarios we should test (and maybe actually have two separate test cases instead of combining it into one):

1) Pod is started with a missing env var.  Pod startup should fail until the env variable is corrected.
2) Pod is started successfully.  The env variable value changes.  A container restart should *not* remount the subpath with the new value. Note that container restart is different from pod restart (deletion and creation).

Sorry I dont understand. I thought that was exactly what I was doing?
Do you mean just split this into 2 e2e tests? Or is it not doing what it is supposed to.

I'm suggesting we split it out into two tests for clarity.  And also, I don't think updating the Pod the second time will trigger a container restart (I manually tried this).  I think the output you are showing is the first scenario from pod startup error -> success.
(Just because the pod annotation got updated doesn't mean that the actual volume mount was updated)
So how do you suggest we do the container restart? I can try and duplicate the subpath functions if thats going to do it?

I discussed with the node team and we couldn't find a great way to trigger a container restart other than using the liveness probe method.

Can the existing subpath methods be imported and reused instead of duplicated?
I can give it a go but I think as they are not public functions they wont be visible. But I will see. They also force probe files at the top of the function so Id have to rework my tests to fit them
I'm fine with making them public
It seems like that container  restart does everything needed in one hit, so I have now split the e2e tests into 3 separate components and this I think should satisfy everything now
indention correct?
